body:
I know of very, *very* few who envision themselves being single their whole lives. The ones that end up that way go SUPER crazy and you can see that in places like +Incels. I have very little sexual or romantic appetite. I've never really had crushes or envisioned myself dating or marrying, men or women, and having sex is even more uninteresting. Oddly enough I lack most sexual instincts too, like showing off status or wanting to look attractive. I've never felt protective of women. I could have an adopted kid and legit don't see the difference between that and a biological child, yet apparently that's supposed to be a big deal or something? Other people sometimes talk about their crushes and romantic dreams like it's natural for them and I'm just completely lost.

I don't feel abnormal but I learned that according to every tenant of biology I'm an absolute anomaly. And then I realized that I've never really met hardly anyone else over the age of 12 who shares my experience. Is this a defect or are other people just acting and playing some weird game?

I kind of wonder whether it was actually Nintendo or if it was really someone else trying to fake excuses to wipe out all remaining channels that aren't directly under the control of Google Inc. We know YouTube hates SML's guts, and in the past 2 years especially we've seen most of the old YouTubers quit (ExplodingTNT, PinkSheep), get rebranded by YouTube Inc. Everyone else who isn't part of the marketing scheme is either dead or buried below everything else and never sees the light of day, SML being one of the last survivors from the old days and they know it's not advertiser-friendly nor good for their desire to control everything like 1984.

body:
Many scholars believe Q was composed in layers. This means it's not exactly its own text with a traditional original autograph and fixed copies of that, but one that's put together and evolves over time. Q was a collection of written material about Jesus based on oral traditions that was expanded over time. I propose that the final version of Q has been under our noses the whole time, and it's even in our bibles under the familiar title of *The Gospel According to Luke*.

My hypothesis is that Luke was written first, perhaps by Mark or Matthew, both of whom the church fathers testify as writing down logia about Jesus out of order, as they came to them. This does not describe the gospels of Mark or Matthew, but it fits an early Q perfectly, which later became Luke. Church fathers also testify that Luke in particular was an absolute mess in the early days, which would be expected from this. The gospel of Mark was based on a very early version of Q/Luke and modified to suit a gentile audience. Matthew, then, must have been composed based on a version of Q at some point in between that of Mark and canonical Luke. The "L" material in Luke is merely content that had not yet been added to Q when Matthew or Mark used it for their gospels. Because of the layered composition of Q, the more primitive nature of Mark compared to canonical Luke does not bar Mark from having copied an earlier Luke. This is easily why Luke is more primitive in wording while Mark is more primitive in content.

I do not believe that Luke ever incorporated Mark; rather, Mark copied a very early, much shorter version of Luke. This makes sense, because [*very* little material is shared only between Luke and Mark, and that little bit is easily explained away by scribal harmonizations. Matthew, on the other hand, has a good chunk of Material shared between only itself and Mark.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Relationship_between_synoptic_gospels-en.svg/360px-Relationship_between_synoptic_gospels-en.svg.png) This implies that traditional Four-Source-Hypothesis of Mark, Q, and M is correct in Matthew's case, and that Matthew knew Mark and Q. But the "Mark" material in Luke is just the earlier parts original to Luke that Mark used as his source.

This resolves several problems:

1. Double agreements: since Mark used Q/Luke as a source, that means most of it overlaps, and since both are used by Matthew, it's not surprising that he would sometimes opt for Luke over Mark. Yet this does not require Matthew to know a Luke like the one we have today, which we also know he didn't have.

2. Luke seems to be the most common source material for other gospels besides just Matthew and Mark. This would make a lot of sense considering it would've been the grand collection of knowledge about Jesus.

3. Luke is noticeably more Hebraic than the other gospels: Mark is more primitive because it's based on a much earlier Luke, but Luke is the most primitive in wording. "Lukan priority" cannot solve this since Mark clearly doesn't know most of Luke, but the concept of an evolving Q can. Much of the Lukan material might even be a direct translation of Hebrew and Aramaic sources, likely including Matthew's supposed Hebrew gospel. What's also interesting is that Shem Tob's Hebrew Matthew often agrees with Luke against Greek Matthew, even though it's Matthew's gospel!

4. No church father mentions Q: they do, however, mention a lot of things about early Luke that resemble Q.

I'm sure there's still problems with this, but nothing that I can come up with. This, among other reasons, means that Luke is probably the most accurate gospel (though definitely not in terms of order, which they couldn't seem to decide on; and excluding the first two chapters as well as the anti-Marcionite revision by the author of Acts).

body:
These are the favorite "proof-texts" for messianic Jews and those who insist that believers must follow the laws of the old testament and Jewish torah:

> 17 “Do not think that I came to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I did not come to abolish but to fulfill. 18 For truly I say to you, until heaven and earth pass away, not the smallest letter or stroke shall pass from the Law until all is accomplished. 19 Whoever then annuls one of the least of these commandments, and teaches others to do the same, shall be called least in the kingdom of heaven; but whoever keeps and teaches them, he shall be called great in the kingdom of heaven. 20 For I say to you that unless your righteousness surpasses that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will not enter the kingdom of heaven.

>    16“The Law and the Prophets were proclaimed until John; since that time the gospel of the kingdom of God has been preached, and everyone is forcing his way into it. 17“But it is easier for heaven and earth to pass away than for one stroke of a letter of the Law to fail.

But considering, like, the entire rest of the book, this makes no sense. A contradictory statement such as this is a sign that it was not written by the original author, but interpolated later by copyists. In the Matthew one, this statement is literally followed by a bunch of attacks on this exact law, where he repeatedly says, "You've heard it said in the law that you should do this, but I'm telling you not to do that, but do this other thing instead". His actions in the rest of all four gospels also do not align with this declaration about the law and he breaks huge tenants of the law.

Also indicating this is how this statement appears in different places in Matthew and Luke, but that is unlikely to have been original given that they used a common source text. "The law and the prophets were proclaimed until John" is also found in Matthew, but the statement about the law doesn't appear there, but in a different location, so it's unlikely that it was in their source gospel. And it would be very hard for both authors to coincidentally conjure up the exact same statement independently. It would make sense, however, for a scribe to find two different places that they think their statement would fit best into the text of each gospel.

Let's see how the Matthean version reads with this text removed:

> 17 “Do not think that I came to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I did not come to abolish but to complete. 20 For I say to you that unless your righteousness surpasses that of the scribes and Pharisees, you will not enter the kingdom of heaven.
> 
> 21 “You have heard that the ancients were told...But I say to you...

This version makes **perfect** sense in light of the context. He came to give the true law, to complete it. The Pharisees were not following this law, but the old law to its letter which was corrupted according to Jeremiah 8:8. Verse 20 follows closely after verse 17, and its reasoning contradicts that of verses 18-19 which try to defend the legalism of the Pharisees. They thought they were justified by doing this, but in reality they weren't. It really seems 18-19, and Luke 16:17 too, were inserted by a scribe who felt uncomfortable portraying Jesus as being against the Jewish law. This could be an Ebionite or Jewish scribe hoping to infiltrate or a church father who was worried that people might read the original version as supporting things like Marcionism, and sought to "clarify" it for them (which was extremely common in ancient times).

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
I don't want anyone to forget that in the first century, the Jews and Romans were involved in an extremely heated culture war even worse than what we have now. It was so bad that they had actually been fighting to take over each other.

The Romans were winning at that point, and the Jews expected a messiah who would join and lead their war against "the ~~seculars~~ pagans" and win it for them. They thought he would help them conquer everything and everyone and rule the whole world, as was currently being done to them. When he didn't do that, they teamed up with the Romans to have him crucified.

Too many these days are acting exactly the same. What are you going to do, you who declare the same things now, when he returns and says the same thing to you? Are you going to try to crucify him again? Because I'm telling you right now that he is not coming to lift you up so you can boast of your righteousness and superiority to all the world. He's not coming to persecute your enemies for you. If that is what you desire, you will be entering the kingdom after many of the people whom you hate.

This is an upcoming feature that will introduce a new feed in the sidebar (along all, trending, etc) called "Featured".

Featured will be comprised of fun, engaging, and interesting posts found across ruqqus; it will be manually curated by the admins with requests from the community.

author.bio:

body:
judge<sup>1</sup>: this word is more in the sense of discerning or forming an opinion.

judge<sup>2</sup>: this word is more in the sense of condemnation.

---

1 Corinthians 4:1-5a

> I don't care much at all if I'm judged<sup>1</sup> by you, or by any human institution. **In fact I don't even judge<sup>1</sup> myself, because I am not aware of anything about myself. But I am not justified by this, and the one judging<sup>1</sup> me is YHWH. So don't judge<sup>2</sup> anything before the proper time, until the master has come**, who will illuminate what is hidden in darkness and expose the motives of peoples' minds.

---

1 Corinthians 5:3-5

> I, being absent in body but present in spirit, **have already judged<sup>2</sup> this person**. I have done this in the name of our master Jesus, with you assembled, and me in spirit, with the power of our master Jesus, **to give this one to Satan for death of the flesh**, so that his spirit might be saved in the day of the master.

1 Corinthians 5:12-13

> What does it mean to me to judge<sup>2</sup> those outside? **Do you not judge<sup>2</sup> those among yourselves? God will judge<sup>2</sup> those outside. Remove the bad one from yourselves.**

1 Corinthians 6:2-3

> Don't you realize that the saints will judge<sup>2</sup> the world? **And if the world is going to be judged<sup>2</sup> by you, are you unfit for the smallest cases?** Don't you realize that we will judge<sup>2</sup> angels? How much more the present reality!

---

There you have it. At one point Paul is telling the Corinthians not to judge under any circumstances, and he makes it clear that this includes *both* believers and non-believers, and even themselves. The next, "Paul" is condemning them for not being judgemental enough, and even prescribes killing one another. In my opinion the second one is a later addition by a redactor who wanted to support the orthodoxy and church authority above the original doctrine of "judge not, lest you be judged" which is more consistent with Paul's opinion's expressed elsewhere. Verses 6:9-11 which finish the passage in support of judging others are also inconsistent with Paul's usual sola gratia theology.

I have done this in the name of our master Jesus, with you assembled, and me in spirit, with the power of our master Jesus, to give this one to Satan for death of the flesh, so that his spirit might be saved in the day of the master.

1 Corinthians 5:12-13

What does it mean to me to judge2 those outside? Do you not judge2 those among yourselves? God will judge2 those outside. Remove the bad one from yourselves.

1 Corinthians 6:2-3

Don't you realize that the saints will judge2 the world? And if the world is going to be judged2 by you, are you unfit for the smallest cases? Don't you realize that we will judge2 angels? How much more the present reality!

There you have it. At one point Paul is telling the Corinthians not to judge under any circumstances, and he makes it clear that this includes both believers and non-believers, and even themselves. The next, "Paul" is condemning them for not being judgemental enough, and even prescribes killing one another. In my opinion the second one is a later addition by a redactor who wanted to support the orthodoxy and church authority above the original doctrine of "judge not, lest you be judged" which is more consistent with Paul's opinion's expressed elsewhere. Verses 6:9-11 which finish the passage in support of judging others are also inconsistent with Paul's usual sola gratia theology.

body: Many idolize the ways of the past, when for most of it Christians would've been arrested and tortured to death in nearly every part of the globe. People were absolutely brutal. Even after that, people were extremely paranoid and society harshly punished even the slightest non-conformity, which would certainly include anything other than their watered-down version of Jesus who is made to embody that culture. I don't see how life was better back then. Yet there is a push in almost every Christian circle I come across to return to those days, as if they were a glamorous golden age of heaven on earth. This is very perplexing to me. Every time I hear about the old days, for the most part I'm very glad I didn't live back then. About the only positive is less mass media. Just what is it that is so great about the past, and why for Christians in particular?

body:
The most jarring example is Shem Tob's copy of the gospel of Matthew in Hebrew. What's bizarre is that it often agrees with *Luke* over Matthew when using the Q source. Interesting, because often the Lukan version is more primitive and Hebraic than the Matthean version. I don't just mean minor details either. For example, the part where the people ask John what to do in chapter 3 is not extant in canonical Matthew, but it *is* in Luke...and a shorter version is also found in Hebrew Matthew! My guess is that Q was originally written in Hebrew, and that Shem Tob's text made use of this or padded it out with translations of the parts of Mark that were incorporated. And Matthew and Luke both made use of some sort of Greek translation of this document. More evidence is that the Shem Tob version also has several agreements with the gospel of Thomas over the canonical gospels, which also utilized Q. As well as agreements with long lost manuscripts not available in his time, so these variants could not have been the results of tampering by Jewish scribes (which did happen, as it also did to the canonical version by Roman scribes).

Some of these old manuscripts also appear to be checked against older sources, including Q, and often the original Hebrew version too. Sinaiticus and Bezae in particular have several variants in the synoptic gospels and even Acts which come from older versions than are available to us today, and updates from source documents that were originally erroneously copied. Some manuscripts of the Old Latin and Old Syriac have similar variants.

The gospel of the Hebrews, too, looks like it made use of this document, or an extremely early version of Luke. I cannot say it *is* Q, as it's definitely edited and harmonized from the existing gospels, but in places it gives a more primitive reading. Such as the beginning: "And it was in the days of Herod king of Judea, during the priesthood of Caiapha, a man named John went..." which is shorter and noticeably more Hebraic than Luke 3:1, and also has an incorrect detail about Herod being king of Judea instead of Galilee (and it's very hard to imagine a redactor editing it to make it shorter and more incorrect).

It may be that the story of the woman caught in adultery is also part of Q, as its style is very Lukan and it appears in a number of early manuscripts in the gospel of Luke instead of John. Perhaps scribes noticed it was not included in any of the canonical gospels and were trying to find a good place to put it before abandoning Q and losing it.

body:
Apparently...these 12 people were assigned work as missionaries to the twelve tribes of Israel. That's about it. Otherwise, they were no different than any other believer. "Apostle" itself is a deceitful term. Most bibles refuse to translate this word to conceal the true meaning, which is, most literally, "one sent", employed to mean a messenger or missionary. *This was an everyday term in the Hellenistic world*. But you are not supposed to know about that. You are supposed to think that the 12 apostles are subordinate gods with authority of their own, and not merely representing the one true god. 

"What about how they wrote scripture?"

I hate to break it to you, but most likely the only apostle who wrote anything in your bible is Paul. Who, by the way, was himself *not* part of the 12, yet still called an apostle, and so were his partners! And what was his work? That's right, he was an evangelist, a missionary, who traveled the world to preach! The letters of the other apostles are either forgeries (some of "Paul's" are too), or a benevolent student of them writing with their name after their death or when they weren't able to, as was considered a noble practice in the ancient world. The bible canon was decided at the council of Rome in 382. We can clearly see that being part of the twelve has no connection to any kind of authority to write "scripture". Even Paul did not realize his letters would be revised and collected into "the bible" and read by millions as more authoritative than Jesus. He was merely writing letters to churches as part of his evangelizing work. Paul, Barnabas, Timothy, and the twelve were no different from what we would call a missionary today, and αποστολος was just the term they used for it back then.

"What about the parts of the bible describing their authority?"

These are later additions by the Catholic redactors. The Acts twelve and the Acts Paul who are basically portrayed as gods have discrepancies their actual descriptions in the gospels and Paul's own letters at almost every point. We are very lucky to have the gospel of Mark preserved with its negative depictions of the twelve to prove this point. Mark is the most primitive gospel and barely made the cut for the canon. And that means it is not edited as extensively to conform with Catholic beliefs. Read about the twelve in Mark, and tell me again how much you trust them to act in Jesus's place. I certainly wouldn't! They were good people, mostly, but they were still human. At its core, the idea that the apostles were some kind of perfect elite and gods on earth is no different from the doctrine of papal infallibility. Each puts its complete faith in a human being!

body:
They want us to think we did. That there's nothing to worry about. In school they teach you that George Washington saved the day, and the monarchists are gone.

Not so, unfortunately. That is a fairy tale. From day one, another enemy, the federalists, have still posed a threat. In the beginning they blatantly wanted a new monarchy. Many of the so-called founding fathers were actually federalists and enemies of the founders of American principles. They forced the true patriots to compromise and set up the framework for a powerful federal shadow government. Do you have rights? Yes, but so do North Koreans, supposedly. The federalists forced us to only forbid the government from infringing on 10 rights, and they are so littered with vague and subjective exceptions that the government can always find a loophole to not protect it. And what is their excuse? The "social contract" that you never agreed to. Free speech for example, is supposedly protected. But there are exceptions, and that's the part they don't teach you in school. These exceptions include "obscenity, fraud, speech integral to illegal conduct, speech that incites imminent lawless action, speech that violates intellectual property law". Btw, that first one, "obscenity" is just an archaic term for what we would now call "offensive". Is this starting to sound familiar? It should to anyone familiar with reddit. The right basically exists only on paper. And every other right we supposedly have is too. Are they generally protected? From other people, yes, but not when the government doesn't like it! And now, the federalists have forced us to compromise to the point where they control two puppet parties and every politician to do their bidding. And they sent us into a state of moral panic to trick us into thinking it's "necessary" to save society. To the leftists, they say white men and muh racism and muh sexism and snowflakephobia is running rampant in everything, and the only way to stop it is to elect political tyrants who promise to crack down. To the right, they say society is infected with gays and trans and feminists and degenerates, and that they will destroy society, and the only way to stop it is to elect tyrannical politicians who will crack down. And it's all a lie, to keep the elites in power while controlling our lives and enjoying our tax dollars, and keep us distracted from it. Wake up people!

body:
![](https://i.ruqqus.com/post/9eli/2fHrUFchKHA)

An inscription found in the Vatican may provide clues with how to go about the modern internet. It reads:

> א]להי ישראל אמר
> 
> כל מודים הם
> 
> גייים ואה[ש

Experts have been able to translate the fragment of text as follows. While such fragmentary text without any context is always questionable, scholars think they've gotten the gist of it:

"g]od of Israel says (or said): 'All mods are gay, and [I will...'"

The stone has been dated to the 7th century BCE, around the time of Isaiah. Many have raised concerns that such a valuable object was kept hidden away in the Vatican for so long, but the pope and /u/spez assured the public that it was lost by mistake.
